message.content:
We want to know what “taxes payable” (a liability on the balance sheet) should show. In many accounting systems – especially when a tax such as VAT is collected – the “taxes payable” balance is computed by “accumulating the tax amount on all (output) sales” (and normally you would “offset” any deductible tax on purchases; but in this problem only the sales transactions carry a tax‐amount). Also, when a new period starts the balance begins at zero (the “initial” balance value). Then as sales occur the “end” balance increases by the tax that is collected.

In the table below the only transactions that record a nonzero “tax_amount” are the sales. (No other type of transaction carries a tax value.) So we must “sum” the tax_amount from every Sale line.

Looking at the provided table the sale transactions and their tax amounts are:

 • Sale20240102001 tax_amount = 14,211.55  
 • Sale20240102002 tax_amount = 13,744.75  
 • Sale20240103004 tax_amount = 14,351.09  
 • Sale20240106006 tax_amount = 9,033.06  
 • Sale20240107008 tax_amount = 102.09  
 • Sale20240108010 tax_amount = 14,296.14  
 • Sale20240110012 tax_amount = 96.27  
 • Sale20240110013 tax_amount = 14,792.99  
 • Sale20240111015 tax_amount = 110.62  
 • Sale20240111016 tax_amount = 13,864.35  
 • Sale20240111017 tax_amount = 9,660.20  
 • Sale20240112018 tax_amount = 687.96  
 • Sale20240123031 tax_amount = 119.21  
 • Sale20240204049 tax_amount = 594.84  
 • Sale20240205052 tax_amount = 2,076.40  
 • Sale20240130040 tax_amount = 10,820.26  
 • Sale20240130041 tax_amount = 13,612.26  
 • Sale20240130042 tax_amount = 115.65  
 • Sale20240131044 tax_amount = 12,058.41  
 • Sale20240131045 tax_amount = 112.79

We add these (step‐by‐step):

 1. 14,211.55 + 13,744.75 = 27,956.30  
 2. 27,956.30 + 14,351.09 = 42,307.39  
 3. 42,307.39 + 9,033.06 = 51,340.45  
 4. 51,340.45 + 102.09 = 51,442.54  
 5. 51,442.54 + 14,296.14 = 65,738.68  
 6. 65,738.68 + 96.27 = 65,834.95  
 7. 65,834.95 + 14,792.99 = 80,627.94  
 8. 80,627.94 + 110.62 = 80,738.56  
 9. 80,738.56 + 13,864.35 = 94,602.91  
 10. 94,602.91 + 9,660.20 = 104,263.11  
 11. 104,263.11 + 687.96 = 104,951.07  
 12. 104,951.07 + 119.21 = 105,070.28  
 13. 105,070.28 + 594.84 = 105,665.12  
 14. 105,665.12 + 2,076.40 = 107,741.52  
 15. 107,741.52 + 10,820.26 = 118,561.78  
 16. 118,561.78 + 13,612.26 = 132,174.04  
 17. 132,174.04 + 115.65 = 132,289.69  
 18. 132,289.69 + 12,058.41 = 144,348.10  
 19. 144,348.10 + 112.79 = 144,460.89  

Thus the total “tax amount” on all sales is 144,460.89.

Since the balance for Taxes Payable is “rolled into the balance sheet” with a zero beginning balance (that is, before any sales occur the tax payable is zero) and then increases by the tax recorded on each sale, we have:

 Initial Taxes Payable = 0.00  
 Final Taxes Payable = 144,460.89

Thus the answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "144460.89"
  }
}
